questions.question: What is the most important factor influencing the focus of light rays on the retina?

options.A: The anterior surface of the cornea
options.B: The posterior surface of the cornea
options.C: The anterior surface of the lens
options.D: The posterior surface of the lens

questions.explanation: The anterior surface of the cornea is responsible for the majority of the eye's total optical power, making it the most important factor in focusing light rays on the retina.

questions.question: How many Purkinje images are formed in a normal eye?
questions.explanation: A total of 4 Purkinje images are formed in normal eyes. Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje-Sanson images. Image Location Direction Image 1: Anterior surface of the cornea, Erect. Image 2: Posterior surface of the cornea, Erect. Image 3: Anterior surface of the lens, Erect. Image 4: Posterior surface of the lens, Inverted. In aphakia, images 3 and 4 are absent, while in a mature cataract, image 4 is absent.

questions.question: The visual axis is the line joining the

options.A: Centre of the cornea to the retina
options.C: Centre of the lens to the cornea

questions.explanation: The visual axis is the line joining the fixation point (object), nodal point (centre of the lens), and the fovea.

questions.question: What is the angle formed between the optic axis and visual axis at the nodal point?
questions.explanation: Angle alpha (α) is the angle between the optical axis and visual axis at the nodal point. Angle lambda (λ) is the angle between the pupillary axis and the line of sight. It is the global tilt offset of the eye when it fixates on a specific target and is a response to the eccentric displaced position of the fovea from the geometrical center of the retina. (Option B) Angle kappa (K) is the angle between the visual axis and the pupillary line at the cornea. It is the only angle that can be measured and is of clinical significance. (Option C) • Positive κ is seen in pseudoexotropia • Negative κ is seen in pseudoesotropia Angle gamma (γ) is the angle between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the center of eyeball rotation. questions.question: A 28-year-old man comes to get his power checked. The optometrist finds the focal length of his lens to be 0.75m; what will be its refractive power?
questions.explanation: Refractive power (dioptre) = 1/Focal length in metres. So, for the given question, refractive power (D) = 1/0.75 = 1.33 D

questions.question: A 6-year-old child complains that she cannot see anything on the whiteboard clearly. On ophthalmological examination, she is found to have a 2 mm shortening of the axial length of the eyeball. How much eye power will this lead to?
questions.explanation: Shortening of 2mm of the axial length of the eyeball will lead to 6D of hypermetropia. In axial hypermetropia, 1mm shortening of the anteroposterior diameter of the eye results in 3 dioptres of hypermetropia. Therefore, 2-mm shortening will lead to 6D of hypermetropia. In curvature hypermetropia, a 1mm increase in radius of curvature results in 6 dioptres of hypermetropia.

questions.question: You are studying the optics of a patient with regular astigmatism. Identify the point at which the clearest image is formed?
questions.explanation: The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing at point D, the circle of least confusion. When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface (surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points. The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of Sturm (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval. For the given Sturm's conoid, • At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays. • At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line. • At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging. • At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion. • At point E, a vertical oval is formed. • At point F, a vertical straight line is formed. • At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

questions.question: What is the Stiles-Crawford effect?

options.A: Cutting off of the peripheral rays by the iris
options.B: High refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
options.C: Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
options.D: More sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays

questions.explanation: The Stiles-Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays. It is one of the natural mechanisms that decrease aberration in the eye. The rays of light that enter through the center of the pupil have higher sensitivity as compared to those entering from the periphery of the pupil. Natural mechanisms that decrease aberrations in the human eye: • Cutting-off of the peripheral rays by the iris • The high refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex • Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina • Stiles-Crawford effect

questions.explanation: Photoreceptors are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

questions.question: You are tasked with studying and mapping the photoreceptor cells in a cohort of patients. Consider the following statements and pick out the false one.

options.A: There are 120 million rods in each human eye.
options.B: Rods produce a hyperpolarizing potential on activation.
options.C: Cones predominate in the extrafoveal region.
options.D: Cones produce a hyperpolarizing potential on activation.

questions.explanation: Cones predominate in the foveal region, not the extrafoveal region. Rods, 120 million in number in each human eye, are receptors for dim/night vision, predominate in the extra-foveal region, are more sensitive to light, contain the pigment rhodopsin, and produce hyperpolarizing potential changes on activation. Cones, 6 million in number in each human eye, are receptors for day vision, predominate in the foveal region, are less sensitive to light, contain the pigment iodopsin, and produce hyperpolarizing potential changes on activation.

questions.question: Which of the following cells are retinal glial cells?
questions.explanation: Muller cells are a type of glial cells found in the retina that help in the binding of the neuronal elements together. They do not take part in the neurosensory pathway of light. Other cells in the retina: Meissner's corpuscles: Tactile receptors localizing in the dermis between epidermal ridges, perceiving touch. Basket cells: GABAergic interneurons found in the cerebellum. Cells Use: Rods and cone photoreceptor cells. S39 Potential Comments: Hyperpolarizing 1st order neurons. Cells Use Potential Comments: Bipolar cells are 2nd order neurons, depolarizing or hyperpolarizing. Amacrine cells connect photoreceptors to ganglion cells, adjusting the relative color and luminosity inputs under changing light conditions. Ganglion cells form the visual pathway, propagating action potential as 3rd order neurons. Horizontal cells increase visual acuity by lateral inhibition, acting as interneurons.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: Rods and cones release Ach at their synapses.
options.D: Bipolar cells show either depolarization or hyperpolarization.

questions.explanation: Rods and cones release glutamate (not acetylcholine) at their synapses. Photoreceptors get hyperpolarized in response to a stimulus, and hence, phototransduction is associated with hyperpolarization. Amacrine cells secrete at least eight types of neurotransmitters, including GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine, and indolamine, all of which function as inhibitory neurotransmitters. Bipolar cells show both depolarization and hyperpolarization.

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for inducing phototransduction?
questions.explanation: Metarhodopsin II is responsible for phototransduction. It activates transducin, a member of G proteins. This leads to the closure of Na+ channels and hyperpolarization, thereby inducing phototransduction (signal transduction in the retina).

questions.question: What is the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum of the human eye?
questions.explanation: The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400-700 nm. Theories of color vision: • Trichromatic theory (Young-Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths; however, each has different spectral sensitivities. • Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems - red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green). • Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture. Trichromatic Theory SMLOMARROW44 Opponent-Process Theory S M L S M L Black-white Red-green Blue-yellow Achromatic System Chromatic System OMARROW

questions.question: What is the characteristic visual defect in deuteranomaly?
questions.explanation: In deuteranomaly, the perception of green color is defective. It is the most common disorder of color vision. Monochromacy: Only one of the three primary colors (red, blue, or green) can be appreciated. Dichromacy: Two primary colors are appreciated (anopia = absent). • Protanopia: Red color is not perceived. • Deuteranopia: Green color is not perceived. • Tritanopia: Blue color is not perceived. Trichromacy: All three primary colors are appreciated, but one of them can be defective (anomaly defective). • Protanomaly: Red color perception is defective. • Deuteranomaly: Green color perception is defective. • Tritanomaly: Blue color perception is defective. Achromatopsia: No color perception due to the absence of cones. It may also occur in the lesion of area V4 or V8 of the visual cortex. 45-92% Normal Vision, 2.7% Deuteranomaly, 0.66% Protanomaly, 0.59% Protanopia, 0.56% Deuteranopia, 0.016% Tritanopia, 0.01% Tritanomaly, <0.0001% Achromatopsia.

questions.question: What is the angle subtended by the optotype on the second line of Snellen's chart when viewed from a distance of 6 meters?
questions.explanation: The angle subtended by the optotype (individual letters on the chart) on the second line of Snellen's chart in the above case would be 30 minutes of arc. The second line on Snellen's chart corresponds to a distance of 36 meters. When viewed from a 6m distance, it is denoted as visual acuity 6/36. Where, the numerator (6) denotes the distance from which the patient is actually viewing it, and the denominator (36) denotes the distance at which it should be ideally viewed. It denotes the distance at which each stroke of the letter would subtend the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of one minute of arc. MAR = 1/Visual acuity. Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of individual limbs of the letters. Hence, the angle subtended by the optotype = MAR x 5. For example, at exactly 6 meters distance from the patient, the letters on the 6/6 line shall subtend 5 minutes of arc (such that the individual limbs of the letters subtend 1 minute of arc). The equation to calculate the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is given as follows: For the given question, MAR = 1/6/36, MAR = 36/6, MAR = 6 minutes of arc. Hence, the angle subtended by the entire letter is 6 × 5 = 30 minutes of arc.

questions.question: A 42-year-old man with monocular aphakia wears contact lenses. What is the approximate percentage of aniseikonia in his eyes?
questions.explanation: The approximate percentage of aniseikonia in a person with monocular aphakia wearing a contact lens would be 8%. Aniseikonia is defined as the difference in image size between the two eyes and can lead to disturbances in stereopsis. The tolerable limit of aniseikonia is 5-8%. It is reduced with a contact lens (8%) compared to glasses (25-30%) in aphakia. However, the percentage of aniseikonia is least with an intraocular lens (IOL) (1-3%), thus secondary IOL implantation is the most preferred management of unilateral aphakia.

questions.question: Which cerebellar nucleus controls the ocular saccade?
questions.explanation: The Floccular nucleus of the cerebellum controls ocular saccades. A saccade is a rapid ballistic movement to change the point of fixation. It is the fastest of all eye movements and is initiated by the contralateral frontal lobe. Smooth pursuit is a slow tracking movement to keep the target on the fovea. It is controlled by the ipsilateral parieto-occipital lobe. Following an object from the right to left is left pursuit and is controlled by the ipsilateral (left) parieto-occipital lobe, and the corrective movement is a saccade (in this case, left to right) termed right saccade and is controlled by the contralateral (right) frontal lobe. The floccular nucleus is found in the lobule X of the cerebellar vermis. Its functions include matching pulse-step, gaze holding, and sustained smooth pursuit. Bilateral lesions of the flocculus result in the following: • Post-saccadic drift - saccadic movements do not stop, but there is a brief, several hundred milliseconds drift of the eyes after each saccade. • Saccadic pursuit - smooth tracking is replaced by simultaneous rapid jerking motions of the eye to follow an object toward the ipsilateral visual field. • Gaze-evoked nystagmus - impaired ability to hold the eyes in the eccentric position, resulting in gaze-evoked nystagmus towards the affected side of the cerebellum. Emboliform and globose nuclei: Generation of vertical saccades. Fastigial nuclei: Pursuit initiation.

questions.question: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body terminate in the primary visual cortex in
questions.explanation: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) terminate in the primary visual cortex in layer 4. Both the magnocellular and parvocellular pathways from the LGB terminate in layer 4 of the visual cortex. Only the interlaminar pathway terminates in layers 2 and 3.

questions.question: What is the mean value for outflow facility of the aqueous in the normal eye?
questions.explanation: The aqueous outflow facility is about 0.28 µL/min/mmHg. Aqueous humor is produced at an average rate of 2.0-2.5 µL/min. The ease with which the aqueous humor leaves the eye is called an aqueous outflow facility. The outflow facility is measured using tonography. The normal range is between 0.22–0.28 µL/min/mmHg. A juxtacanalicular portion of the trabecular meshwork is the primary limiting factor for the outflow facility. Uveoscleral outflow accounts for 10% of the total aqueous outflow facility. Aqueous outflow facility decreases with aging. Trabecular outflow facility is reduced in glaucoma. Laser trabeculoplasty reduces intraocular pressure (IOP) in open-angle glaucoma by increasing the trabecular outflow facility.
